newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish court rejects Welfare plea for more time.
newsitem.headline: Turkish court rejects Welfare plea for more time.

text.p: Turkey's top court on Thursday rejected a request from the main opposition Islamist Welfare Party for an extra three months to prepare its defence against a bid to outlaw it.
"The court unanimously rejected the request for another extension," Anatolian news agency quoted Constitutional Court head Yekta Gungor Ozden as saying.
The Islamist party, the biggest in Turkey's 550-seat parliament, faces closure by the court for allegedly threatening the country's secular constitution in a case opened on May 21.
Welfare's deadline to submit its defence had already been extended by two months to August 4.
The written defence is expected to be judged by the court in closed sessions.
Welfare leader Necmettin Erbakan resigned as prime minister in June after months of pressure from Turkey's secularist establishment led by the military.

His year-long coalition with the conservatives of Tansu Ciller deeply alarmed Turkey's secular armed forces with a series of largely symbolic challenges to the NATO-member country's secular and pro-Western traditions.
The Islamist-led government was replaced by a secularist coalition led by Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz who has promised to take measures to rein in rising religious radicalism.
